pageProps.contentHtml:
entire functions

Consider a map F ⁣:C×C→C\func{F}{\C \times \C}{\C}F:C×C→C with the following properties:

  1. For each fixed z∈Cz \in \Cz∈C the map w↦F(z,w)w \mapsto F\p{z, w}w↦F(z,w) is injective.
  2. For each fixed w∈Cw \in \Cw∈C the map z↦F(z,w)z \mapsto F\p{z, w}z↦F(z,w) is holomorphic.
  3. F(0,w)=wF\p{0, w} = wF(0,w)=w for w∈Cw \in \Cw∈C.

Show that then

F(z,w)=a(z)w+b(z)F\p{z, w} = a\p{z}w + b\p{z}F(z,w)=a(z)w+b(z)

for z,w∈Cz, w \in \Cz,w∈C, where aaa and bbb are entire functions with a(0)=1a\p{0} = 1a(0)=1, b(0)=0b\p{0} = 0b(0)=0, and a(z)≠0a\p{z} \neq 0a(z)=0 for z∈Cz \in \Cz∈C.

Hint: Consider F(z,w)−F(z,0)F(z,1)−F(z,0)\frac{F\p{z, w} - F\p{z, 0}}{F\p{z, 1} - F\p{z, 0}}F(z,1)−F(z,0)F(z,w)−F(z,0)​.
Solution.

Let G(z,w)=F(z,w)−F(z,0)F(z,1)−F(z,0)G\p{z, w} = \frac{F\p{z, w} - F\p{z, 0}}{F\p{z, 1} - F\p{z, 0}}G(z,w)=F(z,1)−F(z,0)F(z,w)−F(z,0)​. By injectivity, F(z,1)−F(z,0)≠0F\p{z, 1} - F\p{z, 0} \neq 0F(z,1)−F(z,0)=0 for any z∈Cz \in \Cz∈C, so z↦G(z,w)z \mapsto G\p{z, w}z↦G(z,w) is entire.

Notice that G(z,0)=0G\p{z, 0} = 0G(z,0)=0 and G(z,1)=1G\p{z, 1} = 1G(z,1)=1. If w≠1,2w \neq 1, 2w=1,2, then by injectivity, F(z,w)≠F(z,0)F\p{z, w} \neq F\p{z, 0}F(z,w)=F(z,0) and F(z,w)≠F(z,1)F\p{z, w} \neq F\p{z, 1}F(z,w)=F(z,1), so G(z,w)G\p{z, w}G(z,w) misses 000 and 111. By Picard's little theorem, z↦G(z,w)z \mapsto G\p{z, w}z↦G(z,w) is constant. In all cases, z↦G(z,w)z \mapsto G\p{z, w}z↦G(z,w) is constant, so

G(z,w)=G(0,w)=F(0,w)−F(0,0)F(0,1)−F(0,0)=w.G\p{z, w} = G\p{0, w} = \frac{F\p{0, w} - F\p{0, 0}}{F\p{0, 1} - F\p{0, 0}} = w.G(z,w)=G(0,w)=F(0,1)−F(0,0)F(0,w)−F(0,0)​=w.

Thus,

w=F(z,w)−F(z,0)F(z,1)−F(z,0)  ⟹  F(z,w)=(F(z,1)−F(z,0))w+F(z,0).w = \frac{F\p{z, w} - F\p{z, 0}}{F\p{z, 1} - F\p{z, 0}} \implies F\p{z, w} = \p{F\p{z, 1} - F\p{z, 0}}w + F\p{z, 0}.w=F(z,1)−F(z,0)F(z,w)−F(z,0)​⟹F(z,w)=(F(z,1)−F(z,0))w+F(z,0).

If we set a(z)=F(z,1)−F(z,0)a\p{z} = F\p{z, 1} - F\p{z, 0}a(z)=F(z,1)−F(z,0) and b(z)=F(z,0)b\p{z} = F\p{z, 0}b(z)=F(z,0), then a(0)=0a\p{0} = 0a(0)=0, b(0)=0b\p{0} = 0b(0)=0, and by injectivity, a(z)≠0a\p{z} \neq 0a(z)=0, which completes the proof.
